The Abe visit doesn't look like it will happen until August.  Trudeau seems to be on a fairly slow march with improved Canada-Iran relations.  Ruhani's late March tweet that Renzi will visit Iran "in the coming months" seems to have put a firm lid on the February Italian announcement that the visit would happen in April.  The Iran run-off elections won't be completed until the end of April.  No one will be able to figure out who won for a while after that, because party affiliation in Iran is sketchy at best.  Let's assume that everything settles down in Iran a couple of weeks after the run-offs.  That's mid-May.  There are no claims of fraud.  There are no surprises or blow-ups.  The coast looks clear.  Let's also assume that there are no government crises in Italy (note to self - Italian governments are prone to crises and tend to be short lived).   How long would it take to plan a Renzi visit?  Maybe 2-3 weeks could be a guess.  So now we are into June.  Of course, "in the coming months" could also mean after July 1.  I might be wrong about this, but I now think I may have been too high on this question for too long.

Visits by heads of state of G7 take a lot of planning and are generally known well in advance. The only confirmed visit is Shinto Abe, prime minister of Japan in August 2016. However, given that some of European leaders have just hosted Iran, it is unlikely they will visit in the next few months, and the issue of Israel is also an outstanding issue for US, Germany, UK.

To make a prediction for this question, I will use the "Norms and protocols of domestic and international institutions matter" method. The relevant "international institutions" include Iran and the countries of the G7 (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). To begin looking at Iran, it is important to consider the effects of its most recent election (http://www.vox.com/2016/3/1/11139970/iran-elections). The election results affirmed the nuclear deal, revealed a push from the Iranian people to open up more to the West, and pointed to a trend of rising moderates in Iran. These effects show a change in the norms and protocols of Iran, whose government has been traditionally been closed off to the West and viewed as "extremist." Because of these apparent changes in norms, it seems more likely than ever that Iran will host a G7 country in the coming months.

July 2016 seems too soon for a G7 head to visit Iran. Though the Austrian head of state visited, that's also the first such visit in years.
